body:
@fkiraly and I think a possible solution to this is to ensure that the train and test datasets have distinct indices, so that when they are concatenated, we do not get any repeated indices.

Might also need to check other datasets to see if there are similar problems

I think the index is generated automatically when loading the files: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/6ee3a7a9e6060b53987dc91335401f02ace3d059/sktime/datasets/_data_io.py#L194

So we could reindex it after loading both the train and test split using something like: `X.reindex(drop=True)`
That's a bad idea, because I think indices in train and test should correspond to indices in the pooled dataset (for traceability/reproducibility).

issue.title: [DOC] data container conventions, conversions, and data sets documentation

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Pull request on data container conventions and related functionality.

This is based on, and branching off the state of #1225 - and requests of @mloning and @TonyBagnall to document this.

The increment in this PR is the notebook `examples/00_datatypes.ipynb` which is supposed to explain:
* the different core in-memory data container datatypes for series and panels used in `sktime`, with examples to play around with
* validity checking, conversion, register, and type functionality
* data sets loading functionality

Ready for review

body:
hm, the problem might be that it has to be fixed upstream in timeseriesclassification.com if we don't do reindexing.

Since this does not seem to happen on a realistic time scale, I'd reverse my opinion and think that re-indexing is fine to make indices unique, for now.

Then, once timeseriesclassification.com fixes this, we can still change the loader.
The same problem seems to be occurring in load_basic_motions too.

issue.title: [ENH] add check for `nested_univ` duplicate index and ensure unique instance index in `sktime` datasets

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This fixes a recurring issue with duplicated indices from the time series classification datasets. This has been repeatedly breaking things downstream and made refactors difficult. Fixes #1290, fixes #2331 for the instance index, addresses the example in #1893 fixes the problem that prevents #2379 to be refactored.

Initial bug report about duplicate indices: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1290

Nature of the fix:
* adds a check for `nested_univ` mtype that prohibits duplicate instance index
* makes changes in the `datasets` module that ensures unique index for loaded time series classification datasets, via `reset_index(drop=True)`
* fixes an instance of duplicate indices in the benchmarking module
* ensures that any `nested_univ` returns of the old `SeriesToSeriesRowTransformer` have unique instance index

Note: this does *not* prohibit duplicate time index, only duplicate instance name (index of the outer `DataFrame` in `nested_univ`).

issue.title: [ENH] refactored `ColumnConcatenator`, rewrite using `pd-multiindex` inner type

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: Restructuring without changing its external behavior. Neither fixing a bug nor adding a feature.

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR is a rewrite of the `ColumnConcatenator`, using `pd-multiindex`.
Originally in https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2369.

The conversion issues are fixed now, should all be good to go.

Relies on the fix to data loaders to ensure unique input index:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3031

---

from first post:

Unfortunately, this has dredged up all kinds of issues with type casting and conversion, so I am isolating it to one PR and removing it from #2369.

The failures in this refactor are linked to the failures in the conversions here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2375, since in the tests we make conversions between the nested data frame format and the `pd-multiindex` format.

rename.to: [BUG] sktime time series classification panel data have duplicate instance indices

body:
Fix: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3029

This is having too many ripple effects, I think we just need to enforce unique instance indices.

issue.body: #3029, but without the checks. Only has the changes that guarantee unique instance index. Fixes #1290.
